message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The excessive growth, large tongue, mass from umbilicus, and hepatomegaly are all signs of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is associated with a mutation in the tumor suppressor gene on the short arm of chromosome 11.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, which is associated with overgrowth and a large tongue. It is caused by a mutation in the tumor suppressor gene on the short arm of chromosome 11. Option B is incorrect as it refers to Neurofibromatosis type 2, option C refers to Down syndrome, and option D refers to Li-Fraumeni syndrome, which are all different conditions with different underlying mechanisms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The excessive growth, large tongue, and mass coming out from the umbilicus suggest Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, which is caused by the mutation in the tumor suppressor gene on the short arm of chromosome 11. None of the other options are associated with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest the boy has Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome (BWS). BWS is caused by genetic and epigenetic changes on chromosome 11, specifically changes in the CDKN1C gene, which encodes a protein that normally inhibits cell division. Therefore, (A) is the correct answer. None of the other options are associated with BWS.

The presenting symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, which is caused by a mutation in a tumor suppressor gene on the short arm of chromosome 11. Option (B) refers to neurofibromatosis, option (C) refers to Down Syndrome, and option (D) refers to familial adenomatous polyposis, none of which are consistent with the patient's presentation.
